headline: Sen. Warner: Russia is fighting a 21st century cyberwar
subHeadline: On 'Your World,' Intelligence Committee vice chairman wishes the Obama administration had put out more information on interference

utterances.speaker: NEIL CAVUTO, HOST
utterances.sentences: Susan Rice, of course, a former national security adviser to President Barack Obama, is set to testify before the Senate Intelligence Committee, all part of that ongoing Russian probe, which brought us to this point, where are right now we in this whole thing? utterances.speaker: NEIL CAVUTO, HOST
utterances.utterance: Susan Rice, of course, a former national security adviser to President Barack Obama, is set to testify before the Senate Intelligence Committee, all part of that ongoing Russian probe, which brought us to this point, where are right now we in this whole thing? Senate Intelligence Committee vice chair, Virginia Democrat Senator Mark Warner, with us right now. Senator, thank you for coming.

utterances.speaker: SEN. MARK WARNER, D-VIRGINIA
utterances.utterance: Neil, thanks for having me on.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: Where does this stand right now? As you have gone -- I know there are some things you can't reveal, and, believe me, I understand that. But is it a sense that you have, Senator, that this thing, the collusion part of it, is closer to being made or has not really been made?

utterances.speaker: WARNER
utterances.utterance: Well, Neil, we keep getting thrown these curveballs. We obviously couldn't have predicted the firing of Jim Comey. We then had the attorney general. Now we have this meeting that Donald Trump Jr. said at first was about Russian adoptions. Now we're up to eight people in the meeting, one of which is somebody who has got at least has a colorful past in terms of potentially money laundering. What we're starting to do now is talk to the people, though, who are affiliated with the Trump campaign that may or may not have had contact with the Russians. So, we're really getting into the meat of it at this point. I wish we'd been further along, but we couldn't have predicted all the twists and turns that we have seen so far.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: You know, Senator, I often hear from both those who, you know, think the president is great and those who think he's not so great, but they think that your committee has it out for him, and that there is a predisposition not to look at any of the stuff that might look bad for the prior administration, fully aware that the Russians might have been involved more ways than thought last summer, and didn't pursue it, thinking Hillary Clinton is going to win in a walk, so they didn't bother. Is there any truth to that? And if there is -- I'm making a leap here -- is it ignored by folks like you and other Democrats?

utterances.speaker: WARNER
utterances.utterance: Neil, first of all, we have the unanimous opinion of the intelligence community that the Russians massively intervened in our elections, in this case to help Mr. Trump and hurt Hillary Clinton. Next time around, they might be -- they might change...

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: So, why didn't Barack Obama just explode that, let that known?

utterances.speaker: WARNER
utterances.utterance: But, Neil, I think -- and I have said this as well, that considering the fact that at least some folks inside the American government knew as far back as last summer, I have said, clearly with hindsight, I wish the Obama administration had gotten more of this information out earlier on. I do think that most of the information and intelligence didn't fully come together until after the election. One of the things that we have unfortunately seen is, even in the aftermath of 9/11, we have way too many silos inside the Intelligence Committee, where I'm not sure everybody is trading information in an appropriate way.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: But don't these revelations, in the weird way, Senator, show you that the intelligence community still misses a lot of stuff? So, when we talk about unanimity on the intelligence front, that's never necessarily a ringing endorsement of intelligence, right?

utterances.speaker: WARNER
utterances.utterance: Well, no, I actually think there's a legitimate criticism that sometimes the intelligence community, until they get all their facts together, don't come up with a complete conclusion. I have rarely seen the intelligence community come up with a complete conclusion. Remember, what we're seeing in terms of the Russians, it just wasn't in the American elections. The Russians also intervened in the French elections. And in that case, Facebook was a little more on the job. Facebook took down 30,000 fake sites before the elections.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: But did anything you see, Senator...

utterances.speaker: WARNER
utterances.utterance: Let me just finish.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: Go ahead. Go ahead.

utterances.speaker: WARNER
utterances.utterance: We have had the Germans -- we have had the Germans indicate they believe the Russians will intervene in the German elections.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WARNER
utterances.utterance: And one of the things that bothers me, if you add up what the Russians spent on intervening in our elections, intervening in the French elections, intervening -- what they will spend intervening in the German elections, you take that you, double it, we're still looking at less than 5 percent of the cost of a new aircraft carrier. My concern is, Russia is fighting 21st century cyber-war, and I'm not sure we're fighting in the same way.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: But, real quickly, Senator, have you seen anything that would tell you now that whatever they did, they influenced the election results?

utterances.speaker: WARNER
utterances.utterance: What I will tell you is, Russians spent a lot of time and effort putting out fake news, fake information, released information on one candidate, not on the other.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: I know that.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: But did they influence the results? Did they tip an election that would have gone to Hillary Clinton?

utterances.speaker: WARNER
utterances.utterance: We don't know in an election that is that close. What we do know is, going forward, 21 states, the Russians tried to hack into.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: All right.

utterances.speaker: WARNER
utterances.utterance: And, unfortunately, DHS has not shared that information with the state election officials.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: WARNER
utterances.utterance: So, what really worries me is, how are we going to be prepared in 2018? That's -- I'm not here to relitigate 2016. I'm here to make sure we're safe in 2018.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: Senator Mark Warner, very good seeing you. Thank you very, very much.

utterances.speaker: WARNER
utterances.utterance: Thank you, Neil. END Content and Programming Copyright 2017 Fox News Network, LLC. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED. Copyright 2017 CQ-Roll Call, Inc.
